{{Featured article}} {{Infobox mineral | name = Yogo sapphire | category = Oxide mineral | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = Yogo2783 Close crop.JPG | imagesize = 150px | caption = A {{convert|0.65|carat|g|adj=on}} AAA quality cornflower blue Yogo sapphire | alt = A {{convert|0.65|carat|g|adj=on}} AAA quality cornflower blue Yogo sapphire | formula = [[Aluminium oxide]], {{chem|Al|2|O|3}} | molweight = | system = [[Trigonal]] | class = Hexagonal scalenohedral ({{overline|3}}m)
[[H-M symbol]]: ({{overline|3}}2/m) | symmetry = ''R''{{overline|3}}c | color = Cornflower blue to purple | habit = Hexagonal, [[Trigonal crystal system|rhombohedral]], [[Prism (geology)|prismatic]] or [[Bipyramid|dipyramidal]] | tenacity = Brittle | twinning = [[Lamella (materials)|Lamellar]] | cleavage = Partings on {0001} and {10{{overline|1}}1} | fracture = Uneven to [[Conchoidal fracture|conchoidal]] | mohs = 9.0 | luster = Adamantine to vitreous | refractive = nω=1.767–1.772
nε=1.759–1.763,
[[Birefringence]] 0.008 | 2V = 58° | opticalprop = Uniaxial (–) [[Abbe number]] 72.2 | pleochroism = Weak | streak = | gravity = 3.98–4.10 | density = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = | other = | references = {{r|minhandbook}} }} '''Yogo sapphires''' are a variety of [[corundum]] found only in Yogo Gulch, part of the [[Little Belt Mountains]] in [[Judith Basin County, Montana|Judith Basin County]], [[Montana]], [[United States]], on land once inhabited by the [[Piegan Blackfeet]] people. Yogos are typically [[cornflower blue]], a result of trace amounts of [[iron]] and [[titanium]]. They have high uniform clarity and maintain their brilliance under artificial light. Because Yogo sapphires occur within a vertically [[strike and dip|dipping]] [[geological resistance|resistive]] [[igneous]] [[Dike (geology)|dike]], mining efforts have been sporadic and rarely profitable. It is estimated that at least 28 million carats ({{convert|5.6|t|abbr=on|disp=or}}) of Yogos are still in the ground. Jewelry containing Yogos was given to First Ladies [[Florence Harding]] and [[Bess Truman]]; in addition, many gems were sold in Europe, though promoters' claims that Yogos are in the [[crown jewels]] of England or the engagement ring of [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Princess Diana]] are dubious. Today, several Yogo sapphires are part of the [[Smithsonian Institution|Smithsonian Institution's]] gem collection. Yogo sapphires were not initially recognized or valued. Gold was discovered at Yogo Creek in 1866, and though "blue pebbles" were noticed alongside gold in the stream [[alluvium]] by 1878, it was not until 1894 that the "blue pebbles" were recognized as sapphires. Sapphire mining began in 1895 after a local rancher named Jake Hoover sent a cigar box of gems he had collected to an assay office, which in turn sent them to [[Tiffany's]] in New York, where an appraiser pronounced them "the finest precious gemstones ever found in the United States".{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=29–31}} Hoover then purchased the original [[mother lode]] from a sheepherder, later selling it to other investors. This became the highly profitable "English Mine", which flourished from 1899 until the 1920s. A second operation, the "American Mine", was owned by a series of investors in the western section of the Yogo dike, but was less profitable and bought out by the syndicate that owned the English Mine. In 1984, a third set of claims, known as the Vortex mine, opened. The term "Yogo sapphire" is the preferred wording for gems found in the Yogo Gulch, whereas "Montana sapphire" generally refers to gems found in other Montana locations. More gem-quality sapphires are produced in Montana than anywhere else in North America. Sapphires were first discovered in Montana in 1865, in alluvium along the [[Missouri River]]. Finds in other locations in the western half of the state occurred in 1889, 1892, and 1894. The Rock Creek location, near [[Phillipsburg, Montana|Phillipsburg]], is the most productive site in Montana, and its gems inspired the name of the nearby [[Sapphire Mountains]]. In 1969, the sapphire was co-designated along with the [[agate]] as Montana's [[state gemstone]]s. In the early 1980s, Intergem Limited, which controlled most of the Yogo sapphire mining at the time, rocked the gem world by marketing Yogos as the world's only guaranteed "untreated" sapphire, exposing a practice of the time wherein 95 percent of all the world's sapphires were heat-treated to enhance their natural color. Although Intergem went out of business, the gems it mined appeared on the market through the 1990s because the company had paid its salesmen in sapphires during its financial demise. [[Citibank]] had obtained a large stock of Yogos as a result of Intergem's collapse, and after keeping them in a vault for nearly a decade, sold its collection in 1994 to a Montana jeweler. Mining activity today is largely confined to hobby miners in the area; the major mines are currently inactive. == Location == {{Location map | Montana | float = right | relief = 1 | label = Yogo Gulch | caption = Yogo Gulch, Montana | lat_deg = 46 | lat_min = 50 | lat_sec = 45 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 110 | lon_min = 18 | lon_sec = 38 | lon_dir = W }} Yogo sapphires are mined in Montana at Yogo Gulch ({{coord|46|50|45|N|110|18|38|W|display=inline|name=Yogo Creek}}),{{r|GNIS Yogo Creek}} which is in [[Judith Basin County, Montana]], {{convert|12|mi|km}} southwest of [[Utica, Montana|Utica]], {{convert|45|mi|km}} west-southwest of [[Lewistown, Montana|Lewistown]], and east of [[Great Falls, Montana|Great Falls]].{{r|carleton|Weed 1900}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=xii, 116}} The site was in [[Fergus County, Montana|Fergus County]] when Yogo sapphires were discovered, but in 1920, because of the re-designation of county boundaries, Judith Basin County was carved out from parts of western Fergus County and eastern [[Cascade County, Montana|Cascade County]].{{r|MT Legislature, County Boundaries|hwymap}} Yogo Gulch and the corresponding natural features of Yogo Peak ({{convert|8625|ft|m}}), Yogo Creek, and the Yogo dike, where the gems are mined, are all in the [[Little Belt Mountains]] within Judith Basin County.{{r|Weed 1900}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=xii, 116}} The Gulch is located along the lower reaches of Yogo Creek and west of the [[Judith River]]. The west end of the Yogo dike outcrops just southwest of Yogo Creek, about {{convert|3|mi|km|0}} north of Yogo Creek's confluence with the Middle Fork of the Judith River; from there it runs east-northeast and ends about {{convert|0.5|mi|m}} from the Judith River.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=116}} Yogo Creek starts just south of Yogo Peak, which is about {{convert|15|mi|km}} west of the Judith River. From there the creek flows southeast into the Middle Fork of the Judith River.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p= 116}} The Judith River then flows northeast from the Little Belts toward Utica. East of the Judith River is Pig-Eye Basin, where Jake Hoover, credited as the person who discovered Yogo sapphires, owned a [[ranch]].{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=15, 116}} {{clear}} [[File:USGS Topo of Little Belt Mts 1902 wscale.jpg|thumb|center|850px|Location of the Yogo mine area from a 1902 USGS topographic map]] === Etymology === Because Yogo Gulch lies in a region historically inhabited by the [[Piegan Blackfeet]] people, promoters of Yogo sapphires claim that ''yogo'' may mean "romance" or "blue sky" in the [[Blackfoot language]],{{r|bluesky|russell11}} although there is little evidence to support this claim.{{efn|No word closely resembling "yogo" appears in modern Blackfoot language dictionaries with any meaning close to the popular speculation of Yogo promoters. The Blackfoot word for the concept of courtship or wooing is ''isawaanopaat'', the word for the color blue is ''ótssko'', and the word for skyward is ''sspóóhtsi'' {{harv|Frantz|Russell|2000|pp=304, 286, and 402}}.}} Other meanings for ''yogo'' have been suggested, including "[[AWOL#Absence without leave|Going over the hill]]".{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=10–11}} The meaning of the word "Yogo" had been lost by 1878, when [[Placer deposit|placer]] gold was found in Yogo Creek. Thus, its true meaning is uncertain.{{r|bluesky|russell11}} == Mineralogy and geology == [[File:Cornflower blue Yogo sapphire.jpg|thumb|A {{convert|0.43|carat|g|adj=on}} pear-shaped cornflower blue Yogo sapphire]] Sapphires are a color variety of [[corundum]], a crystalline form of [[aluminium oxide]] ({{chem|Al|2|O|3}}).{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=ix–xi}} Corundum is one of the hardest minerals, rating 9 on the [[Mohs scale of mineral hardness|Mohs scale]].{{r|gemm}} Corundum gems of most colors are called sapphires, except for red ones, which are called [[ruby|rubies]].{{r|utex}} The term "Yogo sapphire" refers only to sapphires from the Yogo Gulch.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=6–8}} The cornflower blue color of the Yogo results from trace amounts of [[iron]] and [[titanium]].{{r|bluesky}} Yogo sapphires are unique in that they are free of cavities and [[Inclusion (mineral)|inclusions]], have high uniform clarity, lack [[Gemstone#Value|color zoning]], and do not need heat treating because their cornflower blue coloring is uniform and deep.{{r|Kane 2003}} Unlike Asian sapphires, they maintain their brilliance in artificial light.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=31–32}} Yogos present an advantage to gemcutters:{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=62–63}} since they are found as primary constituent minerals within an [[igneous]] [[bedrock]] rather than in sedimentary [[alluvium|alluvial]] deposits where most other sapphires are located,{{r|Weed 1900}}{{r|Kane 2003}} they retain a perfect or near perfect crystalline shape, making cutting much easier, as does their lack of inclusions, color zoning, or cloudiness.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=62–63}} Yogos also exhibit a triangular pattern on the basal plane of the flattened crystals,{{r|trigon}} with thin [[Trigonal crystal system|rhombohedral]] crystal faces, a feature absent in sapphires from other parts of Montana.{{r|O'Donoghue 2006|Kunz 1897|Pratt 1897}} Yogos tend to be beautiful, small, and very expensive.{{r|ethics}} The [[United States Geological Survey]] and many gem experts have stated that Yogos are "among the world's finest sapphires."{{r|usgs}} The roughs tend to be small and flat, so cut Yogo gems heavier than {{convert|2|carat|g}} are rare.{{r|usgs}} Only about 10 percent of cut pieces are over {{convert|1|carat|g}}.{{r|Kane 2003}} The largest recorded Yogo rough, found in 1910, weighed {{convert|19|carat|g}} and was cut into an {{convert|8|carat|g|adj=on}} gem.{{r|usgs}} The largest cut Yogo is {{convert|10.2|carat|g|adj=on}}.{{r|bluesky|distinctly}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=204}} Because of the rarity of large rough Yogo sapphires, Yogo gem prices begin rising sharply when they are over {{convert|0.5|carat|g}}, and skyrocket when they are over {{convert|1|carat|g}}.{{r|O'Donoghue 2006|ethics|distinctly}} Montana sapphires in general come in a variety of colors,{{r|utex|Kane 2003|Kunz 1897}} but Yogos are almost always blue.{{r|distinctly}} About two percent of Yogos are purple,{{r|Kane 2003}} due to trace amounts of [[chromium]].{{r|Gauthier 1995|circa}} A very small number of rubies have been found at Yogo Gulch.{{r|Gauthier 1995}} Yogo sapphires were first discovered in alluvial streambed sediments during [[gold mining]] operations in Yogo Gulch downstream from the Yogo dike, but were later traced to their source within igneous bedrock.{{r|Harlan}} Worldwide, other than the Yogo Gulch deposit and one small site in the [[Kashmir]] region, most other corundum is mined from the sand and gravel created by the weathering of [[metamorphic rock]]. Alluvial sapphires are found in the Far East, Australia, and in three other Montana locations—the upper [[Missouri River]], [[Rock Creek (Montana)|Rock Creek]], and [[Dry Cottonwood Creek (Deer Lodge County, Montana)|Dry Cottonwood Creek]].{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=19–21}}{{r|gemgallerymtloc}} The location of most Yogo sapphires within igneous rock rather than from alluvial placer deposits requires difficult hard rock mining.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=viii, 2–3}} Coupled with American labor costs, this makes their extraction fairly expensive.{{r|utex|O'Donoghue 2006|Pirsson 1897}} At least {{convert|28000000|carat|kg}} are estimated to still be in the ground.{{r|utex|usgs1908}} The Yogo dike is "the only known igneous rock from which sapphire is mined".{{r|Meyer}} The sapphire bearing Yogo dike is a dark gray to green [[intrusive rock]] known as a [[lamprophyre]]. The lamprophyre is an unusual igneous rock that contains a low content of [[silica]]. The rock has a [[porphyritic]] texture with large crystals of [[orthopyroxene]] and [[phlogopite]] set in a fine grained [[Matrix (geology)|matrix]]. The phlogopite crystals have been used to determine the age of the dike and its crystallization temperature (900 °C (1,650 °F)). The dike also contains fragments of other rock types. These [[xenolith]]s include pieces of limestone, [[clastic]] [[sedimentary rock]]s, and [[gneiss]]. In some locations, due to the abundance of xenoliths, the dike has the appearance of a limestone [[breccia]] in an igneous matrix.{{r|Harlan}} One gneiss fragment found as a xenolith contains corundum. The Yogo sapphires themselves are rimmed with a reaction layer of [[spinel]] and are etched, indicating that the sapphires were not in [[chemical equilibrium]] with their host, the lamprophyre magma. This suggests the sapphire crystals may have originated in an earlier rock, such as a corundum-bearing gneiss, later assimilated by the lamprophyre magma at depth.{{r|Harlan|Meyer}} Earlier investigators had assumed that the sapphire had crystallized from the magma with the necessary high aluminium content provided by assimilation of clay rich [[shale]]s of the [[Proterozoic]] [[Belt Supergroup]] sediments which are known to be present at depth in the region.{{r|Pirsson 1897}} [[File:PurpleY6Br.jpg|thumb|left|A {{convert|0.37|carat|g|adj=on}} brilliant cut purple Yogo sapphire. Only about two percent of Yogo sapphires are purple.]] The Yogo dike is a narrow subvertical sheet-like igneous body. It varies from {{convert|2|to|26|ft|m}} thick and extends for {{convert|5|mi|km}}, [[strike and dip|striking]] at an azimuth of 255°. The dike is broken into three offset [[en echelon veins|en echelon]] segments,{{r|Harlan}} and dates to 48.6 [[Mya (unit)#Symbols y and yr|mya]] using [[Argon–argon dating|Ar dating]] on phlogopite. The dike intrudes [[Mississippian age]] (360 to 325 mya) limestone and other sedimentary rocks of the [[Madison Group|Madison]] and [[Big Snowy Group]]s.{{r|Harlan}} There has been considerable debate over the years as to the depth of the Yogo dike and how many ounces of rough sapphires per ton it contains. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Delmer L. Brown, a [[geological engineer]] and gemologist, conducted the most thorough scientific exploration up to that time, concluding that the dike was at least {{convert|7000|ft|m}} deep and that the concentration of rough sapphires was not constant throughout the deposit.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–158}} Brown found that the dike had intruded into a pre-existing [[Fault (geology)|fault]] that had been a conduit for groundwater circulation. The overlying shale, the [[Kibbey Formation]], was deposited on an [[unconformity]], an ancient Mississippian-age [[karst]] [[erosion surface]],{{r|USGS1979}} and was not intruded by the dike.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–158}} This groundwater action produced collapsed zones which were intruded by the dike to form breccia zones. Recent erosion in the area removed the overlying shales and again exposed the limestone to groundwater action which produced collapse breccias which include fragments of the dike rock. He determined that the erosion of the dike in the current erosion cycle was minimal.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–158}} Brown also showed that the unique characteristics of the Yogo sapphires are related to their geological history. Most sapphires are formed under low pressure and temperature over geologically short periods of time, and this is why most non-Yogo sapphires have imperfections and inconsistent coloring.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–158}} Yogos show crystalline formation under very high temperatures and pressures corresponding to a great depth, over geologically long periods of time.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–158}} Brown also showed that distribution of gem rough through the dike was not consistent, so using an average "ounces per ton" was misleading. For example, the section which, despite several ownership and name changes over the years, is generally known as the "American Mine," was developed in an area dominated by post-dike breccia with significantly lower ounces per ton than the English Mine.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–158}} == Montana sapphires == [[File:LgYellowSapphire.jpg|thumb|right|An uncut/rough yellow sapphire found at the Spokane Sapphire Mine near Helena, Montana]] "Yogo sapphire" is the preferred term for gems found in the Yogo Gulch, whereas "Montana sapphire" generally refers to gems found in other Montana locations.{{r|Kane 2003}} More gem-quality sapphires are produced in Montana than anywhere else in North America.{{r|Kane 2003}} Montana sapphires come in a variety of colors, though rubies are rare.{{r|utex|Kane 2003|Kunz 1897}} The first sapphires found in the United States were discovered on May 5, 1865, along the Missouri River, about {{convert|14|mi|km}} east of [[Helena, Montana|Helena]], in [[Lewis and Clark County, Montana|Lewis and Clark County]], by Ed "Sapphire" Collins.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=6–8}}{{r|Kane 2003}} Collins sent the sapphires to [[Tiffany's]] in New York City, and to Amsterdam for evaluation;{{r|Clabaugh bulletin}} however, those sapphires were of poor coloring and low overall quality, garnering little notice and giving Montana sapphires a poor reputation.{{r|edcollins}} Corundum was also found at Dry Cottonwood Creek near [[Butte, Montana|Butte]] in 1889, Rock Creek near [[Philipsburg, Montana|Philipsburg]] in 1892, and Quartz Gulch near [[Bozeman, Montana|Bozeman]] in 1894.{{r|Kane 2003}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=19–21}}{{r|mtkids}} By 1890, the English-owned Sapphire and Ruby Mining Company had bought several thousand acres of land where Montana sapphires were found, but the venture failed after a few years because of fraudulent practices by the owners.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=16–19}} Sapphires from these three sites are routinely heat-treated to enhance color.{{r|Kane 2003}} While millions of carats of sapphires have been mined from the Missouri River deposits, there has been little commercial activity there since the 1990s because of the high cost of recovery and environmental concerns. Production at Dry Cottonwood Creek has been sporadic and low-yielding. The Rock Creek area, also known as Gem Mountain, continues to be the most productive site in Montana, even more so than Yogo Gulch, producing over {{convert|190000000|carat|g}} of sapphires since its inception in 1906.{{r|Kane 2003}} Other than Yogo, Montana sapphire mines have been less successful because they have few blue sapphires and non-blue sapphires have low profit margins.{{r|mtdeq}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=76–78}} These gems inspired the names of features: the mountains near Rock Creek are known as the [[Sapphire Mountains]]. [[Garnet]]s are also found at some Montana sapphire sites, inspiring the name of the [[Garnet Range]], which lies to the north of the Sapphire Mountains.{{r|garnet}} In 1969, the sapphire and [[agate]] were jointly declared Montana's two official [[List of U.S. state minerals, rocks, stones and gemstones|state gemstones]].{{r|mtkids|mtlaw}} == History == [[File:A Quiet Day In Utica - CMRussell.jpg|thumb|''A Quiet Day In Utica'' by [[Charles Marion Russell|C.M. Russell]]|300px]] Mining of Yogo sapphires was exceptionally difficult and remains sporadic today. Even so, Yogo sapphire mining turned out to be more valuable than several gold strikes.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=viii, 2–3}} The Yogo area also produced small amounts of silver, copper, and iron.{{r|mtdeq}} Yogo Gulch lies in a region originally inhabited by the Piegan Blackfeet people.{{r|bluesky|russell11}} Gold was first discovered at Yogo Creek in 1866, but the small numbers of early prospectors were driven off by local [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]].{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=10–11}}{{r|mtdeq}} During a [[Gold Rush]] in 1878, about a thousand miners came to Yogo Creek, which was one of the gold-bearing streams in Montana not yet actively mined. "Blue pebbles" were noted along with small quantities of gold. The mining camp at Yogo City only flourished for roughly three years,{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=10–11}} and eventually the population dwindled to only a few people.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=10–11}} Yogo City was briefly known as Hoover City,{{r|taliaferrohoover}} after Jake Hoover. Hoover was part of a partnership that had been [[placer mining]] for gold and is credited as the discoverer of Yogo Sapphires.{{r|mtdeq}} For several years, he also owned a ranch in nearby Pig-Eye Basin. He later prospected for gold in [[Alaska]] and was a deep-sea fishing guide in [[Seattle]] before eventually returning to the Judith Basin.{{r|mtdeq}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=109–112}} Western painter [[Charles Marion Russell|C.M. Russell]] arrived in the area in 1880 as a young cowhand and was hired by Hoover.{{r|artmt}} Russell stated that he learned most of his frontier skills from Hoover,{{r|mtkids}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=22–30}} and the two men remained lifelong friends.{{r|artmt}} Millie Ringold, a former slave born in 1845,{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=21}} settled in [[Fort Benton, Montana]] after having worked as a nurse and servant for an army general. When gold was discovered at Yogo Creek, Ringold sold her boarding house in Fort Benton and left for the Yogo gold fields, setting up a hotel, restaurant, and saloon in Yogo City where she sang and played music.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=21}} Ringold later cooked for the English mine, but also worked her own gold claims, even after gold mining was on the decline.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=71–73}} She was known as a superb cook and ultimately died in Yogo City in 1906, the last resident of the community.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=21}}{{r|millie}} The nearby town of Utica was featured in Russell's 1907 painting ''A Quiet Day In Utica'',{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=27–30, 110–113}}{{r|srm}} which was originally known as ''Tinning a Dog''. Hoover, Ringold, store owner Charles Lehman, and Russell himself are all depicted in the painting, placed between the hitching post and door of the general store.{{r|srm|cmrussell|twm}} === Discovery === [[File:YogoPeakP318.jpg|thumb|Yogo Peak seen from the Belt Creek Divide, c. 1900]] In 1894, the "blue pebbles" were recognized as sapphires.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=31–32}}{{r|Harlan}} One story credits a local school teacher for recognizing the blue pebbles as sapphires.{{r|Russell Country, Yogo Gulch}} A variation is that the teacher lived in Maine, but was a friend of a local miner, who had mailed her a small box with some gold and a few "blue pebbles" in it.{{r|mtdeq}} Another story credits a miner named S.S. Hobson for surmising that the blue stones might be sapphires, and his guess was confirmed by a jeweler in Helena.{{r|mtdeq}} Ultimately, in 1895, Jake Hoover sent a cigar box containing those he had collected while mining gold to an assay office, which in turn sent them via regular, uninsured mail to Tiffany's in New York City for appraisal by Dr. [[George Frederick Kunz]],{{r|Kane 2003}} the leading American gemologist of the time.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=3–4, 29–31}} Impressed by their quality and color, Kunz pronounced them "the finest precious gemstones ever found in the United States".{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=29–31}} Tiffany's sent Hoover a check for $3,750 (approximately ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|3750|1895|r=-2}} }} as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}),{{r|bigsky}} along with a letter that described the blue pebbles as "sapphires of unusual quality".{{r|Harlan}} === Early mining === Yogos were ultimately traced from the alluvium to their source.{{r|Harlan}} In February 1896, a sheepherder named Jim Ettien found the sapphire [[mother lode]]: the Yogo dike.{{r|trigon|bigsky}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=32–35}} Ettien was prospecting for gold, and found sapphires after washing gravel he found in a fissure within a limestone outcrop.{{r|mtdeq}} Ettien staked two claims. The vein turned out to be {{convert|5|mi|0}} long and several other miners promptly staked claims along it.{{r|mtdeq}} Ettien sold his claims to Hoover;{{r|trigon|bigsky}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=32–35}} Hoover in turn sold his interest in eight original mining stakes, known as the "New Mine Sapphire Syndicate", to his two partners for $5,000 (approximately ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|5000|1896|r=-4}}}} as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}).{{r|usgs1908}} This site was {{convert|5|mi|0}} from Yogo City.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=71–73}} In 1899, Johnson, Walker and Tolhurst, Ltd. of London purchased the New Mine Sapphire Syndicate for $100,000 (approximately ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|0.1|1899|r=1}} }} million as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}). At that point, the operation became unofficially known as the "English Mine".{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=36–42}} On July 4, 1896, two other Americans, John Burke and Pat Sweeney, staked six mining claims on the western portion of the Yogo dike—areas Hoover had deemed unfit for mining. These claims were collectively known as the "Fourth of July Claim", and became known as the "American Mine". In 1904, the mine was bought by the American Gem Syndicate, and it sold in 1907 to the American Sapphire Company.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=74–76}} [[File:YogoFace1897P456.jpg|thumb|Face of the Yogo dike in open cuttings in 1897]] One of the Englishmen who came to the area was Charles Gadsden of [[Berkhamsted]], [[Hertfordshire]]. By 1902, Gadsden was promoted to resident supervisor of the English Mine, and he quickly turned its focus from gold to sapphires.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=71–73}} Gadsden's security measures were very tight, as weight-for-weight, rough sapphires were and continue to be worth much more than gold.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=80–81}} The English Mine flourished until the 1920s,{{r|bigsky}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=36–42}} but floods on July 26, 1923, so severely damaged the mines that they never fully recovered.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=102–109}} Between the aftermath of flooding and hard economic times, the English Mine finally failed in 1929.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=102–109}} It had recovered more than {{convert|16|e6carat|t}} of rough sapphires that produced {{convert|2.5|e6carat|kg}} of finished gems valued at $25 million in 1929 dollars (approximately ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|25|1929|r=-1}} }} million as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}).{{r|utex|Kane 2003}} A series of other firms mined sapphires there, but with marginal success.{{r|mtdeq|bigsky}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=36–42}} For much of the 1930s and 1940s Gadsden worked the mine alone and used his own money to pay its property taxes.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=117–122}} He remained caretaker of the mines until shortly before his death on March 11, 1954.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=122–130}} The American Mine operations were less profitable than those of the English Mine. While the English Mine used superior mining and management techniques on a richer lode, the American Mine suffered from insufficient space and lack of water for ore weathering. Roughs from the English Mine were shipped to London and sold in Europe, often with claims they were sapphires from the Far East, while the American Mine had difficulty marketing its gems within the United States. The American Sapphire Company, which used local [[gemcutter]]s from [[Great Falls, Montana|Great Falls]], went bankrupt in 1909; a new firm, the Yogo American Sapphire Company, bought the American Mine, but was bankrupt by 1913. Gadsden and his wife had convinced the New Mine Sapphire Syndicate to buy out the Yogo American Sapphire Company in 1914, and in doing so, the English syndicate gained control of all known Yogo deposits. They quickly recouped the purchase price by washing the [[tailings]] left behind by previous operators of the American Mine.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=57–64}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=75–77, 95–96}} === 1940s–1970s === [[File:YogoMine1897P456.jpg|thumb|Mine shaft in Yogo Gulch, 1897]] Montana sapphires were heavily mined during {{nowrap|[[World War II]]}} for industrial abrasive and cutting purposes. However, because the Yogo mines were still owned by the English, the United States government could not control those operations, so the mines were little affected by the war, even though industrial sapphires were critical to the war effort.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=122–130}} The Yogo Sapphire Mining Corporation of [[Billings, Montana]], was the next company to try to run the English Mine. They made an initial offer in 1946, and reached a deal by 1949. However, the purchase was not complete until 1956 because of legal issues. The sale was finally completed for $65,000 cash and some stock considerations because the company's capital was exhausted, similar to previous Yogo ventures. The Yogo Sapphire Mining Corporation then changed its name to be the same as the former English firm's name: New Mine Sapphire Syndicate. It became informally known as the "American Syndicate" to distinguish it from the previous "English Syndicate". Production was poor and mining ceased in September 1959.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=125–134}} From 1959 to 1963, the mine itself was left unattended and unsecured, resulting in hobbyists, picnickers, and [[Amateur geology|rockhounds]]' coming from all over the US and Canada to gather loose rough sapphires. The American Syndicate took action to stop this in 1963, with fences and threats of prosecution.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=134–135}} The American Syndicate then tried leasing the mine to several operators. One of these was Siskon, Inc. of Nevada, which lost a significant amount of money.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=136–138}} They sued, and in May 1965 the Montana Supreme Court ruled in Siskon's favor.Siskon Corp v. New Mine Sapphire Syndicate, 145 Mont. 346, 400 P. 2d 867 (1965) Siskon bought the mine at a sheriff's sale and in turn leased it to a group headed by Arnold Baron, who had a background in gemcutting and jewelry. Baron organized German and [[Thai people|Thai]] gemcutters and had success in marketing Yogos in America—the first such success in 50 years. However, owing to the difficulty in mining the hard rock site, he did not exercise his option to buy the mine, and Siskon sold it in August 1968 to Herman Yaras of [[Oxnard, California]], for $585,000.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=136–138}} [[File:YogoDikeP420.jpg|thumb|150px|left|The sapphire-bearing dike on right side of photo, c. 1900]] In 1969, Yaras' Sapphire Village, Inc. created the Sapphire Village, a nearby homesite development offering buyers limited mining rights to gather their own sapphires with hand tools. Having done no significant mining or marketing, Sapphire Village, Inc. sold in 1973 to one of its investors, Chikara Kunisaki, a celery farmer from Oxnard, California. Kunisaki renamed the business Sapphire International Corporation and attempted to create a commercial mining operation. He built a modern {{convert|3000|ft|m|adj=on}} tunnel at the site of the old American Mine, named the "Kunisaki Tunnel". But operation costs were so high that Sapphire International Corporation shut down in late 1976.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=138–144}} This was the last actual attempt to mine the American Mine section of the Yogo dike, and today, only the locked portal to the tunnel still exists.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=207}} In January 1977, Victor di Suvero and his firm Sapphire-Yogo Mines became the next owner to tackle the Yogo dike. Di Suvero was a native-born Italian who grew up in [[Tientsin, China]], and had been successful with a [[jade]] mine in California. Di Suvero's expertise was in marketing: he formed a company called Sapphire Trading to cut and market the Yogos. He had novel marketing ideas but was not knowledgeable about the mining side of the business. Unable to make payments, his venture folded in late 1979.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=144–150}} By 1980, only four American owners had been successful at Yogo Gulch, all early in its mining history.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=144–150}} The English syndicate had been the most profitable of any venture, and even that venture was short-lived.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=36–42}} At least thirteen American-owned Yogo mining efforts had failed. Besides inherent difficulties with financing and the challenges of hard rock mining, the American owners generally did not understand how to effectively market the gems.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=144–150}} === 1980s and beyond === Kunisaki put his mine up for sale, asking $6 million to recoup his expenses. Even though mine profits had been poor over the decades, prices of precious gems were very high at the time due to the worldwide oil crises of the 1970s and early 1980s. Four individuals or groups seriously considered Kunisaki's offer.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–154, 158–164}} Relying heavily upon Delmer Brown's expertise, Harry C. Bullock and J. R. Edington formed the limited partnership American Yogo Sapphire Limited, becoming the 14th American company to work the Yogo dike. Bullock and Brown had Yogo mine experience, as they had worked with di Suvero. Bullock's plan included mining, cutting, making jewelry, and marketing—the whole spectrum of the business. They paid the $6 million asked by Kunisaki and then raised another $7.2 million in funding by October 1981. Brown located quality gemcutters in Thailand, and set up the American Yogo Sapphire Company there. Brown also set up a thorough, computerized security system that tracked gems from the mine to the gemcutters.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–154, 158–164}} Bigger roughs were sent to American cutters, specialty cuts were done in Germany, a few cuts were done in Hong Kong, and the vast majority were done in Thailand.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=158–159}} American Yogo Sapphire Limited secured a $5 million line of credit with [[Citibank]]. Desiring a more modern name, American Yogo Sapphire Limited changed its name to Intergem Limited in early 1982. Intergem marketed the Yogo as the "Royal American Sapphire." Their first line of jewelry appeared in mid-1982, first marketed regionally in the American west and later at the national level. Intergem also developed a system of authorized dealers,{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–154, 158–164}} and found success in its first four years, with sales over $3 million in 1984 alone.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=181–187}} [[File:Thai Gem Cutting.jpg|thumb|left|Gemcutting in [[Thailand]]]] Intergem rocked the gem trade by marketing the Yogo as the world's only guaranteed untreated sapphire. By 1982, the practice of routinely heat treating gems had become a major issue in the industry.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=151–154, 158–164}} At the time, 95 percent of all the world's sapphires were being heated to enhance their natural color. Thai traders had even purchased large quantities of naturally colorless Sri Lankan sapphires, known as [[geuda]], and heated them to an artificial blue.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=165–181}} A problem with the practice was that heated gems often fade over time, though trained gemologists can detect a heated gem with 95 percent accuracy. Intergem's marketing of guaranteed untreated Yogos set them against many in the gem industry.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=165–181}}{{r|richards}} In 1985 there was a movement in Pennsylvania to require disclosure that a gem had been treated. Intergem's strategy resulted in large numbers of gem professionals visiting Yogo Gulch.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=181–187}} Intergem began planning to dig even deeper into the Yogo dike, which held more known reserves than all the world's other known sapphire deposits combined, albeit deep underground rather than near the surface in the manner of the other known deposits.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=185–191}} They also set up a washing plant and maintenance sheds at the site of the former American mine.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=207}} Intergem had made a $1.5 million down payment and agreed to make semi-annual payments to Kunisaki's Sapphire International Corporation, which had been renamed to Roncor. Intergem also had loan and interest payments on the $7.2 million loan to make to Citibank. While the company's sales were steadily increasing, their profits were still too low and in May 1985 they missed a $250,000 payment to Roncor. Simultaneously, their collateral of gems, held by Citibank, declined because the value of their collateral was declining; as a result, Citibank called in its loan. Intergem had over $1 million in sales lined up for the 1985 Christmas season, but could only fill a tiny portion because they did not have enough operating capital to manufacture the Yogo jewelry. In mid-1986, Roncor regained full ownership even though Intergem had sold loose gems and jewelry worth millions of dollars.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=185–191}} Various companies attempted to lease the mine from Roncor, but in the meantime, two local couples, Lanny and Joy Perry and Chuck and Marie Ridgeway, discovered a new site at Yogo Gulch in January 1984 by following a trail to an unused section of the dike that had previously been deemed unsuitable. They began mining the site and named it the "Vortex Mine", forming a company named Vortex Mining. The mine shaft was {{convert|280|ft|m}} deep and contained two Yogo ore-bearing veins.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=193–195}} The portion of the dike they had mined was an extension of the main dike.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=196–198}} The Vortex Mine, renamed Yogo Creek Mining,{{r|Kane 2003}} was successful for years but eventually declined and closed in 2004.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=196–198}} [[File:Point-19 carat diamond cut blue Yogo sapphireCROP.jpg|thumb|A {{convert|0.19|carat|g|adj=on}} diamond cut cornflower blue Yogo sapphire]] In 1992, Roncor found an {{convert|11|carat|g|adj=on}} rough.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=196–198}} AMAX Exploration, operating as the Yogo Sapphire Project, signed a 22-month lease with Roncor in March 1993 and had some success in the middle and eastern portions of the dike; it decided not to continue after the end of its lease due to the cost of underground mining, depletion of easily accessible Yogos, and the relatively small size of Yogos then easily accessible. During this time, additional dikes were found in the area using [[geophysics|geophysical]] [[magnetometer]] surveys. Low-grade sapphire rough was found in the Eastern Flats Dike, a parallel dike some 500 feet northeast of the main dike.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=198–201}} Pacific Cascade Sapphires, a Canadian company, had a mining lease with Roncor in 2000 and 2001 but ran out of funds and their option expired. By this time, most of the easily accessible Yogos had been mined and miners had to dig deeper, further increasing costs.{{r|Kane 2003}} In 1995, Intergem's stock of gems began to reappear on the market because the company had paid its salesmen in sapphires during its financial demise. After Intergem collapsed, many of its salesmen continued to sell Yogos, especially after AMAX ceased operations. Citibank also had obtained a large stock of Yogos, reputedly worth $3.5 million (approximately ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|3500000|1985|r=-2}} }} as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}), as a result of Intergem's collapse: {{convert|200000|carat|g}} of rough, {{convert|22000|carat|g}} of cut gems, and 2,000 pieces of jewelry, all of which sat in the bank's vaults until 1991 when Sofus Michelsen, director of the Center for Gemstone Evaluation and creator of the ''Michelsen Gemstone Index'', became interested.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=200–203}} In 1992, he and Jim Adair, a [[Missoula, Montana]], jeweler who is the world's largest retailer of Yogos, got together, and by October 1994 Adair had purchased Citibank's four sealed bags of Yogo material. However, only one of the bags was truly valuable. Adair and Michelsen designed custom cutting techniques for Yogos.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=201–207}} A new owner, Michael Duane Roberts, bought the Vortex Mine in 2008. Its operations were designed to be environmentally friendly, using methods such as recycling all water and not using other chemicals.{{r|distinctly}} Roberts died in a mining accident in 2012.{{r|Greatfalls}} {{as of|2011}}, there was also mining activity by individual hobby miners on small parcels at Sapphire Village, but the Roncor mines remained inactive.{{r|usgs}} In 2017, Vortex Mines was sold to Don Baide who plans to continue operations.{{cite news|last1=Higgs|first1=Levi|title=How Montana Gold Rushers Literally Threw Away a Fortune in Sapphires|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/how-montana-gold-rushers-literally-threw-away-a-fortune-in-sapphires|accessdate=17 January 2018|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=12 January 2018}} == Notable specimens == [[File:Detail - Conchita Sapphire Butterfly head with Yogo sapphire crop - 2011-01-07.jpg|thumb|right|Large blue Yogo sapphire in the head of the Conchita Sapphire Butterfly, created in 2007, currently held by the Smithsonian Institution]] Several Yogo sapphires are kept at the [[Smithsonian Institution]]. The earliest donations were noted in the museum's annual report on June 30, 1899, when the institution reported that Dr. L. T. Chamberlain gave them two cut Yogos and 21 other sapphires for their Dr. [[Isaac Lea]] gem and mineral collection.{{r|lea}} The record-setting {{convert|10.2|carat|g|adj=on}} cut Yogo is also held by the Smithsonian.{{r|bluesky|distinctly}}{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=204}} In 2006, gemologist Robert Kane of Fine Gems International in Helena, which has the world's largest selection of Montana sapphires, donated 333 Montana sapphires, weighing a total of {{convert|27.07|carat|g}}, to the [[National Museum of Natural History#Hall of Geology, Gems, and Minerals|Smithsonian's Gem and Mineral Collection]], along with 98.48 grams of 18K yellow gold for the creation of a piece of jewelry.{{r|conchita2|conchita3}} A representative of the Smithsonian asked Paula Crevoshay, a jewelry designer from [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]], to create a piece of finished jewelry from these gems.{{r|conchita1|conchita3}} Crevoshay felt that a butterfly motif would best represent America's natural beauty, honor her mother's love of butterflies, and display the wide range of colors found in Montana sapphires. Crevoshay named the brooch "Conchita" in honor of her mother; it is also referred to as the "Sapphire Butterfly Brooch", "Conchita Sapphire Butterfly", and the "Montana Butterfly Brooch". Two of the sapphires used are [[cabochon]] cut and the rest are brilliant cut.{{r|conchita1}} The majority are from the Rock Creek deposit. The largest one, however, is a blue Yogo used for the butterfly's head. Other sapphires used included yellow, purple, pink, and orange gems. Crevoshay completed the brooch in 2007; she and Kane presented the finished brooch to Smithsonian curator Jeffrey Post on May 7, 2007, in Washington, DC.{{r|conchita1}}{{r|conchita4}} [[File:Tiffany and Company Iris Corsage Ornament Walters 57939 Detail croped.jpg|thumb|left|Detail of the Tiffany Iris Brooch by [[Paulding Farnham]] circa 1900, currently held by the [[Walters Art Museum]]]] In the earliest years of Yogo sapphire mining, before Yogos achieved their own reputation, Oriental sapphires were sold in Montana with claims they were Yogos, while in Europe, Yogos were sold as Oriental sapphires.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=61–62}} However, Yogos became notable in their own right. [[Paulding Farnham]] (1859–1927) used Yogos in several jewelry pieces he designed for the [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|1900 Exposition Universelle]] in Paris,{{r|zapata}} where Yogo sapphires received a silver medal among all gems for color and clarity.{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=57–58}} An entry of uncut loose Yogo sapphires also won a bronze medal at the [[Louisiana Purchase Exposition|1904 Louisiana Purchase Exposition]] in [[St. Louis, Missouri]].{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=93}} Farnham was the creator of the most elaborate piece of jewelry ever made with Yogos, the life-size Tiffany Iris Brooch, a brooch ornament, which contains 120 Yogo sapphires set in platinum,{{sfn|Voynick|1985|pp=114–115, 204}} and sold on March 17, 1900, for $6,906.84.{{r|farnham}} In 1923, [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Florence Harding]] was given an "all Montana" ring made from a Yogo sapphire and Montana gold. In 1952, Gadsden gave cut Yogos to [[Harry Truman|President Harry Truman]], his wife [[Bess Truman|Bess]], and their daughter [[Margaret Truman|Margaret]].{{sfn|Voynick|1985|p=204}} Many Yogos were also sold in Europe, as some Yogo mining was conducted by British interests.{{r|distinctly}} Yogos may have been in the personal collections of some members of the British royal family in the 1910s,{{r|distinctly}} but promotional claims that Yogos are in any of the crown jewels of England cannot be conclusively proven or disproven.{{r|distinctly|mtkids|rockmt}} Claims that the gem in the engagement ring of [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Lady Diana Spencer]] and [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Kate Middleton]] is a Yogo are dubious; the gem is thought to be of Sri Lankan origin.{{r|crown}} The story that the gem is a Yogo can be traced to a 1984 ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' article that described the ring as a {{convert|9|carat|g|adj=on}} sapphire, and quoted Intergem president Dennis Brown's claim that the gem may have come from a British-owned Yogo mine.{{r|Sanko February 3, 1984}} {{clear}} == See also == * [[Bismarck Sapphire Necklace]] * [[Hall Sapphire and
